A **ghast**, Z, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"). It is a low-level [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") being similar to a [ghoul](/wiki/Ghoul "Ghoul"): it is [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous"), [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid"), [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless"), [unbreathing](/wiki/Unbreathing "Unbreathing"), and can [follow](/wiki/Follow "Follow") the player character to other levels.

Ghasts share the ghoul's paralyzing claw attack, and also have a second claw attack and a bite attack. They possess [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"), [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), and [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance").

## Generation

In addition to random generation, a [Necromancer](/wiki/Necromancer "Necromancer") using the [raise zombies](/wiki/Raise_zombies "Raise zombies") technique on a [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") corpse without a matching [zombie](/wiki/Zombie "Zombie") form has a 1⁄4 chance of creating a ghast.

Ghasts may leave an old corpse upon death.

## Strategy

Ghasts are fairly non-threatening: they are slightly weaker than ghouls in SLASH'EM and its variants, they move at a slow 6 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"), and their melee attacks have very mediocre damage output. A ghast also has no [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") or [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") to speak of, making them easy to hit and kill. Their paralysis attack is unlikely to cause too much harm unless you are already surrounded, and can be prevented with [magic cancellation](/wiki/Magic_cancellation "Magic cancellation") or [free action](/wiki/Free_action "Free action").

## Origin

Ghasts are purely a modern fantasy invention, derived simply from the word *ghastly* and its resemblance to *ghostly*; NetHack's ghasts specifically appear to derive from D\&D. Curiously, the spelling of the word *[ghastly](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ghastly)* itself also derives from similar confusion with the word *ghost*: *ghastly* derives from the Old English root 'gast' meaning "to torment, frighten" while "ghostly" comes from a root meaning "spirit", but during the standardization of English spelling in the 16th century, *gastly* was standardized to *ghastly* due to its resemblance in both form and meaning to *ghost* or *ghostly*.

Ghasts share the ghoul's paralyzing claw attack, and also have a second claw attack and a bite attack. They possess cold resistance, sleep resistance, poison resistance, and drain resistance.

Generation

In addition to random generation, a Necromancer using the raise zombies technique on a humanoid corpse without a matching zombie form has a 1⁄4 chance of creating a ghast.

Ghasts may leave an old corpse upon death.

Strategy

Ghasts are fairly non-threatening: they are slightly weaker than ghouls in SLASH'EM and its variants, they move at a slow 6 speed, and their melee attacks have very mediocre damage output. A ghast also has no AC or MR score to speak of, making them easy to hit and kill. Their paralysis attack is unlikely to cause too much harm unless you are already surrounded, and can be prevented with magic cancellation or free action.

Origin

Ghasts are purely a modern fantasy invention, derived simply from the word ghastly and its resemblance to ghostly; NetHack's ghasts specifically appear to derive from D&D. Curiously, the spelling of the word ghastly itself also derives from similar confusion with the word ghost: ghastly derives from the Old English root 'gast' meaning "to torment, frighten" while "ghostly" comes from a root meaning "spirit", but during the standardization of English spelling in the 16th century, gastly was standardized to ghastly due to its resemblance in both form and meaning to ghost or ghostly.
